data.title: TexturePacker exception message doesn't contain the filename
data.body:
When there is a problem with an image, I don't know which image have caused the error. Could use something like above to avoid this?

TexturePacker.java 635. line:
throw new RuntimeException("Error packing images. (The last processed image was: " + input + ")" , ex);

Thank you!

data.title: Powering off Xbox controller is ignored by gdx-controllers extension
data.body:
When calling `Controllers.getControllers()` in the render code and check for the size (number of controllers plugged in) it doesn't change when I plug out/power off the controller.

This gets problematic when implementing support for dynamic controller plugging.

data.title: Make Model extendable
data.body: When extending the Model class, to avoid copy/pasting the whole file, prefer protected method. It's a start.

data.title: lwjgl linux; liblwjgl.so: wrong ELF class: ELFCLASS32
data.body:
Using 1.8.0, old LWJGL works fine, but I can't get new one to start.

The liblwjgl.so under /tmp is 32 bit, though the one under target/natives is 64 bit. (I tried manually replacing it, but it's recreated each time as far as I can tell).

```
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM warning: You have loaded library /tmp/libgdxjunkdog/1c78875b/liblwjgl.so which might have disabled stack guard. The VM will try to fix the stack guard now.
It's highly recommended that you fix the library with 'execstack -c <libfile>', or link it with '-z noexecstack'.
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /tmp/libgdxjunkdog/1c78875b/liblwjgl.so: /tmp/libgdxjunkdog/1c78875b/liblwjgl.so: wrong ELF class: ELFCLASS32 (Possible cause: architecture word width mismatch)
    at java.lang.ClassLoader$NativeLibrary.load(Native Method)
    at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary0(ClassLoader.java:1929)
    at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1814)
    at java.lang.Runtime.load0(Runtime.java:809)
    at java.lang.System.load(System.java:1083)
    at org.lwjgl.system.Library$1.load(Library.java:25)
    at org.lwjgl.system.Library$1.load(Library.java:22)
    at org.lwjgl.system.Library.loadLibrary(Library.java:196)
    at org.lwjgl.system.Library.loadSystem(Library.java:90)
    at org.lwjgl.system.Library.<clinit>(Library.java:48)
    at org.lwjgl.system.MemoryUtil.<clinit>(MemoryUtil.java:56)
    at org.lwjgl.system.libffi.Closure.<clinit>(Closure.java:57)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl3.Lwjgl3Application.initializeGlfw(Lwjgl3Application.java:64)
    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.lwjgl3.Lwjgl3Application.<init>(Lwjgl3Application.java:73)
    at se.feomedia.map.MapApplicationDesktopNoSwing.main(MapApplicationDesktopNoSwing.java:21)
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
    at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
    at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:483)
    at com.intellij.rt.execution.application.AppMain.main(AppMain.java:144)
```

data.title: getDesktopDisplayMode()
data.body:
Using this with 1.8.1 libgdx nightly back end

if I set :

```
cfg.fullscreen = true;
cfg.width = LwjglApplicationConfiguration.getDesktopDisplayMode().width;
cfg.height = LwjglApplicationConfiguration.getDesktopDisplayMode().height;
```

I get this:

```
Exception: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError thrown from the UncaughtExceptionHandler in thread "main"
```

getDisplayMode() doesn't exist in 1.8.1 nightlies.

If I manual set width/height it works fine (or if I don't set).

It's using the old/current LWJGL back end (2.9.2).  Windows 7 64bit.

data.title: Issue #3698: Fixed wrong Y property in case of Tile Object in TMX map
data.body: This fixes issue 3698.

data.title: TMX map loader: wrong "y" property on Tile objects with flipped Y.
data.body:
The Tmx Map loader places objects wrong in the Y axis coordinate when the flipY flag is true.

How to reproduce:

1.- Create a TMX map in tiled.
2.- Create an object layer.
3.- Add a tile object to the layer in any position and remember the position.
4.- Retrieve the layer, and afterwards the object, through TmxMapLoader.
5.- Check "y" property after retrieval.

LibGDX version: 1.7.2
Tiled version: 0.14.2

data.title: Added GL3 context creation. Ported GL version checks from Lwjgl backend.
data.body: Contribution to #3673. Changes to get Lwjgl3 backend running with our GL3 project.

data.title: Wrong dependency project name when setting up new project for Eclipse
data.body:
I have created a new project using the gdx-setup.jar tool available from https://libgdx.badlogicgames.com/download.html with the option to generate the .project files for Eclipse.

After importing the projects in Eclipse, I can see that the configuration is wrong: the Java Build Path includes a project named "my-gdx-game-core" but it doesn't exist. I am able however to include the project name "core" that is on my workspace.

data.title: Gdx.app.exit() doesn't work on HTML platform
data.body:
I found an `exit()` call for a `GwtApplication` in the [JavaDocs](https://libgdx.badlogicgames.com/nightlies/docs/api/com/badlogic/gdx/backends/gwt/GwtApplication.html) but it isn't automatically called when i execute the code `Gdx.app.exit()`. Am I misunderstanding this use case for this or how I am supposed to do this? Is it not implemented? I'm just expecting the browser tab to close...

System Details
OS: Windows 10 Home Edition
Arch: x64
Browser: Google Chrome Version 47.0.2526.106 (latest)

data.title: rotateBy surpasses 360 & 0
data.body: While the rotation looks fine on screen, the number output is wrong. It should clamp to 0, and 360, then roll over to the next value as it goes past either. The reason I request this is i'd like to rotate to an angle by the shortest route. I realized this is tricky to calculate when the rotation surpasses 360deg.

data.title: Blender model being displayed skewed after applying parenting with automatic weights.
data.body:
Hi everyone and happy new year!

I've decided to experiment a little bit with 3D Modelling, Texturing, Skinning and Animation with Blender and for this purpose I've followed this tutorial https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vUFRnU1xEYw .

I managed to create an object and import it in Libgdx, but the model is somehow getting skewed.
The problem is occuring after I've applied the parenting between the mesh and the bones. In Blender as you can see everything is proportioned and working perfectly fine. After exporting the model without applying any parenting between the bones and the mesh everything is being displayed fine, but after I applied "Set parent to with automatic weight" as mentioned in the tutorial and exported the model I've got those strange skewing effects.
What I've tried until now
- recalculating normals, clear transformations, recalculating rolls, exporting as G3DJ, changing the UP direction.
  Its not just a simple rotation. The whole mesh is somehow strangely skewed and I don't know how to fix it.

Does anyone have any idea?
Thank you!

![image01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16527359/12079615/73101dfa-b248-11e5-935c-233baaa6e327.png)

data.title: Bullet wrapper - disable generating finalizers
data.body:
I think SWIG generating finalizers should be disabled for the Bullet wrapper. As far as I understand, all the objects should be manually disposed (as in all libgdx code?), so the finalizers are just slowing down GC.

SWIG manual reference to disable generating finalizers: http://www.swig.org/Doc1.3/Java.html#performance

data.title: M!
Shrinking a Pixmap with interpolation / smoothing.
data.body:
I am trying to shrink Pixmaps with interpolation.
In the docs it says I can use this to get smooth resizing with `pixmap.drawPixmap(...)`:

```
Pixmap.setFilter(Pixmap.Filter.BiLinear);
```

When I tested this, I could produce a nice interpolated image when the size is increased, but if the size is reduced, the results look identical to when `Pixmap.Filter.NearestNeighbour` is used. I.e. no smoothing.

Is this a bug or a feature with the `Pixmap.Filter.Bilinear`? Am I doing something wrong? Is there maybe an alternative way of shrinking Pixmaps smoothly?

Thanks!

data.title: VM Crash using Pixmap#dispose on Win64
data.body:
The Java VM crashes in some circumstances when Pixmap#dispose is called. I can't reliably reproduce it, it just occurs randomly, regardless of the manner in which it is called.

Here is the VM crash log, http://pastebin.com/bV5xtVc7

Using LibGDX 1.7.2 on Windows64

data.title: Grammatical errors in `CONTRIBUTE.md`
data.body:
By section:
## Using the issue tracker

"feature" should be singular
## Pull requests

Capitalize "GDX" in "libGDX" (3 times), capitalize "H" in "GitHub", use "send" instead of "sent", make the URL a link
## CLA

Make the e-mail a `mailto:` link, filling in the subject automatically
## Eclipse formatting

Capitalize "GDX", getting rid of a list with only one item
## Performance considerations

Capitalize "GDX" (x2), format correctly the package name
## Git

Capitalize "GDX", fix ordering of letters in "GDX" and capitalize, fix 2 run-on sentences, use a plural noun for "ourselves", "changes" is one word, and "request" is used in a singular context.

data.title: ScalingViewport ignores screenX and screenY position
data.body:
ScalingViewport ignores screenX and screenY position. Because of this, while using two FitViewports with different position on screen, it would not move it there. I've fixed it by adding current screenX and screenY position into update() method of the ScalingViewport. I could create pull request, but I should know if this is a bug, or intended.

```
setScreenBounds(getScreenX() + ((screenWidth - viewportWidth) / 2), getScreenY() + ((screenHeight - viewportHeight) / 2), viewportWidth, viewportHeight);
```

data.title: Sprite.getColor.a is equal to 0.99607843 instead of 1. Sprite.setAlpha(1) does not work.
data.body: If I create a new Sprite (sprite = new Sprite(new Texture(Gdx.files.internal("badlogic.jpg")))) by default sprite.getColor().a should be 1 but it is instead 0.99607843. Also, if I try sprite.setAlpha(1) and sprite.getColor.a = 1 and sprite.setColor(new Color(1,1,1,1) then sprite.getColor().a is still 0.99607843 instead of 1.

data.title: TextureAtlas addRegion API (Texture)
data.body:
Hi,

Maybe not so much of an issue, but I'm confused as to why a single textureatlas can contain multiple textures, isn't the point of an atlas to have only one texture with different regions, or is the purpose of this function something else?
